RADIO AND TELEVISION SINGAPORE
(Conversion into statutory board)


    1. Mr Ang Nam Piau asked the Minister for Communications and Acting Minister for Culture if he will consider setting up Radio and Television Singapore as a statutory body.

     The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Culture (Dr Ow Chin Hock) (for the Minister for Communications and Acting Minister for Culture): Mr Speaker, Sir, the answer is yes. In fact, the

Government has agreed to the establishment of Radio and Television Singapore as a statutory board. Legislation will be introduced as soon as possible to establish the new Board.

NEWSPAPER COMPANIES
(Compliance with Newspaper and Printing Presses Act)


    2. Mr Yeo Choo Kok asked the Minister for Communications and Acting Minister for Culture (a) how many newspapers have complied with the provisions of the Newspaper and Printing Presses Act within the stipulated period; and (b) how many individuals hold 3% shares in those newspapers.

Column: 1037



     Dr Ow Chin Hock (for the Minister for Communications and Acting Minister for Culture): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Newspaper and Printing Presses Act stipulates that no person shall hold more than 3% of the ordinary shares in a newspaper company. All the newspaper companies with the exception of Singapore Publishing Company Limited (publisher of Min Pao Daily) have complied with this provision within the stipulated period. There were two shareholders in the Singapore Publishing Company Limited who held ordinary shares in excess of 3%. As they have passed away, distribution of their shares to meet the 3% requirement awaits the settlement of claims to their estate.

    The answer to part (b) is 48. As on 12th March, 1979, a total of 48 individuals hold 3% shares in those newspaper companies that have complied with the provisions of the Act.

RETAIL PRICE OF SUGAR


    3. Mr Ang Nam Piau asked the Minister for Trade and Industry why the retail price of sugar to Singapore consumers is so high in relation to the world price, and if the Government will consider subsidising the difference between the current Singapore price and the world price so as to reduce the price in Singapore.

     The Minister for Finance and Acting Minister for Trade and Industry (Mr Hon Sui Sen): Mr Speaker, Sir, it is not appropriate to judge the domestic price of sugar at any one point of time or only when the world prices are lower. Sugar prices often fluctuate rapidly on the world market. To ensure security of supplies of raw sugar and to help maintain the stable domestic selling price for refined sugar, the Sugar Industry of Singapore has had to enter into long term supply contracts. The long term contracts with Australia and Fiji, concluded towards the end of 1974, assured us of raw sugar supplies for 1975 to 1977, and thereafter up to 85% of our domestic requirements until 1980. The contracted price at $689 per metric ton was then extremely favourable compared to the prevailing market price of about $2,580 per metric ton.

Column: 1038



    Thus, the Sugar Industry of Singapore was able to maintain the domestic retail price of refined sugar at $1.24 per kg from 1974 to April 1978 and at $1.20 per kg since then. Otherwise, Singapore consumers would have had to pay as much as $3.72 for their kilogram of sugar if they had to buy on the open market at the peak of world price fluctuations. Taking the period between 1974 and now, the price paid by our consumers on the average is about 7 cts per kg lower than the average world price of white sugar.

    We should therefore look at the price of sugar on a longer term basis and not be misled by the difference between the current Singapore price and the world price. There is no ground for Government to consider subsidising sugar prices when the average price paid by Singapore consumers is lower than the average world price. Moreover, to subsidise to lower the price of sugar is to invite disaster. We do not grow sugar. Many a developing country that has sought popularity by subsidising rice, sugar and other essential foodstuffs have distorted their economy and suffered endless economic woes. We must learn from other people's unhappy experiences.

     Mr Ho See Beng (Khe Bong): Sir, I would like to ask the Minister for Finance why tariff protection is still accorded to sugar and not to flour.

     Mr Hon Sui Sen: Sir, in the case of sugar, the price has been based on a long term contract which has been entered into by a company in which the Government has full control and can be certain of the cost of manufacturing. In the case of the Sugar Industry of Singapore, I think we have roughly 40% of the equity, and we are therefore in some control. We know exactly what is happening in the company.

    In the case of flour, the consumption of flour from the mill is only a part of the total capacity of the mill which is also designed for export. Moreover, there are different varieties and it would be very difficult to control the price of flour. Also, the price of wheat flour fluctuates to such an extent that the mill

Column: 1039

should be asked to compete on a world basis. It would be to the interest of the Singapore consumer that wheat flour should not be controlled.

     Mr Ho See Beng: Sir, from the consumers' point of view, if we allow the import of sugar, does the Minister not think that we can also bring down the cost of sugar, so that this will benefit the consumers?

     Mr Hon Sui Sen: Of course, the price of sugar can be cheaper when the world price is lower. It can also be very much dearer, and I mentioned that it could be $3.72 per kilogram, which was the price at its peak in 1973 or 1974.

     Mr Hwang Soo Jin (Jalan Kayu): Mr Speaker, Sir, would the Minister inform the House as to whether there is a limitation on the margin of profit that the Sugar Industry of Singapore is allowed to make, in view of the fact that the sugar industry is a protected industry?

     Mr Hon Sui Sen: Sir, the profit which is allowed to the Sugar Industry of Singapore is determined by the Government, I think it has been around 8% on the equity, only on domestic operations. If they can make money, for example, on export, I allow them the full profit because this is not a matter which should be controlled by the Government.

    In the same way, if they can, in buying the sugar or paying for it, make a profit on exchange, I think that is also a legitimate profit which should be allowed to the Sugar Industry of Singapore. On the other hand, of course, if they make a loss that would be entirely, again, charged to them.

     Haji Sha'ari bin Tadin (Bedok): Sir, yesterday we had a very interesting debate when this House adjourned, and we were all very impressed by the excellent replies given by the Minister for National Development in answer to queries raised by Members in this House.

    Sir, I would like to raise a few points with regard to problems in my constituency. First, I would like to raise this question of providing urinals in void decks close to children's play-grounds. In fact, I raised this matter last year, but I feel that it is still a pressing problem because the situation has not improved. I still get complaints from residents during my block tours that children continuously urinate in lifts. They do so simply because there are no toilet facilities near where they normally play. When they get the urgent call of nature, they go to the most convenient private place, i.e. the lift. The result needs no elaboration. I would therefore once again like to suggest that urinals be built near children's play-grounds or play areas. Such public urinals need not be an eye-sore. They can be taste-fully designed and, if looked after properly, will not cause any unpleasant effect on the environment.

    Children will not normally go all the way to hawker centres, markets or commercial premises, or even go back to their flats, to answer the call of nature. The suggested public urinals will thus do a great service not only to children but also to people who have to attend wedding receptions in the void decks. I have also received a similar complaint from these people.

    Sir, perhaps the Hon. Minister would like to consider the feasibility of a pilot scheme in

Column: 1041

Bedok in one or two void decks, although I know that similar projects were carried out in Bukit Ho Swee.

    The question of allowing the void decks to be converted for use as recreational facilities for the residents, like the aged or the senior citizens, should be considered. In my speech during the debate on the Presidential Address, I did mention the need for such purpose.

    The void deck seems to be a convenient place for the residents to meet, discuss, have indoor games, relax. So why can the HDB not allow some selected void decks to be partitioned off for such purposes? In the one-room blocks of flats, these partitioned void decks can also be used by students for study or as a reading room.

    The other question which I would like to ask the Hon. Minister, and for which I have received frequent complaints from the residents of Apartment Block 15, is the hazards posed by the bin centre located between the market and the hawker centre at Block 16, Bedok South Road. The complaint is about the foul smell from the bin centre. It is carried by the wind to the homes of residents living in the lower floors of Block 15 which is very close to the centre. Lately, according to the residents, the stench has become unbearable, especially at night. The situation has become unconducive to healthy living. The place has become alive with rodents. The cause of all this is probably due to an overheap of rubbish from the market, especially on Sundays, and the failure to clean the bin centre at regular periods.
2.45 p.m.

    In addition to this, I was told by the residents that they were sometimes awakened by the clanging noise of metallic bins being thrown about on the floor in the night. I should appreciate it if the Hon. Minister could look into this complaint because the several complaints made in the past did not bring about any action by those concerned. Perhaps it would be a good idea if the Hon. Minister could look into the possibility of resiting the said bin centre away from the flats, and in the meantime

Column: 1042

ensure that the rubbish is promptly removed and the place cleaned up regularly.

    Lastly, Sir, may I know whether the Minister would consider increasing the number of community halls. At the moment, it is one community hall per constituency, especially in the case of housing estates in new towns. I find the attitude of our Singaporeans, especially those who live in high-rise flats, is that they want everything at their doorstep. At the moment the community hall is located in the void deck of Block 39, Bedok South. This facility is open to residents, the residents' committees, and also the Citizens' Consultative Committees for their use, without any charge. Those who live in Bedok North will never make use of this facility because of the inconvenience of distance. Therefore, Sir, there is a need to have another community hall in Bedok North or Neighbourhood Ill to serve the residents in that neighbourhood.

     Mr Ho Kah Leong (Jurong): Sir, I join my colleagues here not so much to criticise the HDB for the shortcomings of its day-to-day administration as I do not have HDB flats in my constituency. I merely want to bring up a point which, I think, is not unreasonable. At present the HDB imposes a debarment period of 30 months on private house owners after they have disposed of their properties to rent or purchase HDB flats. This is indisputable. However, to apply the same debarment ruling on JTC flat dwellers, I think, is a bit unfair, as after all HDB or JTC flats are considered low-cost housing. The general policy governing the ruling and leasing of such flats is almost identical.

    Sir, as rules are man-made, they can be modified to suit the needs of changing circumstances. We have seen that at one time when JTC flats in Boon Lay were over-built, applicants for HDB flats were persuaded to take up the vacant flats there. So here, the relevant interchangeability between HDB and JTC is not at all impossible. Therefore, I see no reason why JTC flat dwellers have to be subjected to the debarment period when they wish to apply for HDB flats. Sir, I would like the Minister concerned to clarify this point.

Column: 1043



     Mr Tan Soo Khoon (Alexandra): Sir, in the Housing Board estates the HDB engages contractors to clean common areas. However, the contractors often do not do the job satisfactorily. Common corridors, stair-cases, lifts and open spaces remain dirty. Sir, although complaints of this nature had been raised in this House before, and I was one of those who brought up this point last year, it appears that little improvement has been made to rectify the situation.

    Sir, from my own observation, it appears to me that the HDB and its Area Offices are unable to keep check on and supervise effectively the work of the cleaning contractors. To me, this seems to be the weakness in the system. I would like to impress upon the Minister that closer supervision of the contractors is essential in order that our housing estates remain clean so that the people can continue to live in a clean environment. I would also like to ask the Minister whether there are penalty clauses in the contracts signed with the HDB's cleaning contractors, and whether such penalties are enforced if the contractors do not do their work properly.

    The second point I would like to bring to the Minister's attention refers to complaints made by residents of HDB estates to the Area Offices. Very often I hear from my own constituents that their complaints to the Area Offices are not attended to. It has been brought to my attention that in quite a number of instances people who go to the Area Offices get the brush-off from those at the counters. As a result residents get very frustrated, if minor complaints such as broken doors or the lighting in the corridors goes out of order are not even attended to. I would like to urge the Hon. Minister to impress upon the staff of the HDB and its Area Offices that they should take note of complaints from residents more seriously and that follow-up action should be instituted with minimal delay.

     The Chairman: Would you like to reply now, Mr Teh?

     The Minister for National Development (Mr Teh Cheang Wan): As there are only

three more speakers on this Amendment, I would like to hear them first.

     The Chairman: All right. Mr Yap.

     Mr Eugene Yap Giau Cheng (Mountbatten): Sir, I would like, first of all, to thank the Hon. Minister for allowing me the opportunity to speak now, instead of keeping me waiting.

    Sir, the Housing and Development Board has beyond a shadow of doubt done exceedingly well in providing cheap and quality homes, and the meticulous way in which the HDB's 1977/78 Annual Report is being presented (and this is my first experience of it), appears to be very beautiful. This stands witness to the beautiful and organised way in which things are being done by the Housing and Development Board. But, Sir, there are still a few ugly spots which need to be put right. If these ugly spots are eradicated, it will make the whole HDB machinery move nearer towards perfection. If the Hon. Minister would like an analogy, I can think of a beautiful face but requiring a little bit of surgery to straighten a crooked nose. A few examples, Sir, will probably help to explain what I mean.

    In my house-to-house visits, in my meet-the-people sessions, and in my campaigns during the recent by-elections, I received complaints about HDB staff not treating my constituents the way they ought to. Actually this point has just been brought up by the hon. Member for Alexandra. I do agree that there are people who are very difficult to deal with, people who would not even listen to any explanation, etc., but surely in this particular case, the saying that the customer is always right does hold true too. I believe that a little bit of diplomacy and tact on the part of HDB staff will help the situation very much. My sympathies go with them but I feel that in this particular case we can still achieve zero-defect even in public relations. I do not know whether the HDB rotates their staff, but if they do not as yet rotate their staff, may I humbly suggest to the Hon. Minister to consider rotating their staff so that those who are on PR work will not all the time be subjected to this humdrum of

Column: 1045

meeting difficult people. Take them away for a while and bring them again to the front line. It would be prudent for me to stress that the complaints I have received are only on a very small number of HDB staff, but it is worth a thought as it does add a blemish to the good name of the HDB.

    Closely related to this problem of my constituents is the delay my constituents face when they complain of problems concerning their homes. Again, the Member for Alexandra has brought this up, but I feel out of conscience that I must bring it up again. They complain of weather-beaten doors, leaky pipes and roofs, etc. But the problem is not with the complaint but the time taken to attend to the complaint. What I think the HDB staff can do is, again as I mentioned sometime ago, to actually put themselves in the position of the complainants. Then they will realise the difficult conditions that the residents have to bear. This I call "empathy". I do appreciate that problems take time to solve, but surely it does not need to take more than a year or two. Here, I beg your permission, Sir, to quote from Volume 35, col. 1079 of the Hansard [24.11.76] and this reply was given by the then Minister in 1976.

    'There are certain types of repairs which necessarily take a longer time to complete, e.g., defective doors and windows in the older buildings have to be individually measured and hand-made as the standard-sized mass-produced windows and doors cannot be used. In a number of instances repairs were delayed because no one was in the flat when the workmen called.'

    This is the reply which I found in the Hansard as an answer to my predecessor's question in 1976. Sir, it is 1979 now and I believe nothing much has been done, because the people who complained in 1976, I believe, are also the people who are complaining today. This is the result of my discussion with them during my house-to-house visits. It is my sincere hope that the HDB will consider precipitating some action as soon as possible.

    Another matter is lift breakdowns. Lift breakdown is giving my constituents problems because they live in flats with only one lift. When the lift breaks down, the older folks have to climb up seven floors, or more. I

Column: 1046

believe the Minister has given an answer yesterday and this problem has also been brought up in the Chamber many, many times. All I want to add here is that I trust quick action will be taken to solve the problem. I am glad, as a first timer standing in this Chamber, complaining of HDB lifts, to note that there is such a thing as a central control team, so says the 1977/78 HDB Annual report, at which the head office receiving a call, round the clock, directs requests for emergency repairs to Service Teams at the Area Office. In this way, says the report, residents can receive prompt response to breakdowns in essential services. This appears to me like the SWAT Squad which was a television feature some years ago and which many try to emulate. I wish the HDB, Sir, good luck in emulating the SWAT Squad But if we go back to the Hansard again, the then Hon. Senior Minister of State for National Development did reply to Mr Ivan Baptist when he brought this up. He said that they were looking into a method to improve the mechanical part and quality of the electrical contact and control parts of the lifts. I hope a solution has been found by now.
3.00 p.m.

    Another problem, Sir, is the chicken and egg situation. I do not know which comes first. My reasoning is that if there was no HDB, this problem would not arise, and therefore I am bringing this up under this amendment. It is this question which the Hon. Minister was talking about in terms of "swimming pools", not for human beings but for mosquitoes. I find that quite a lot of "swimming pools" have been "constructed" for mosquito breeding at construction sites. The mosquitoes there are not little ones but the big giant ones. They are obviously intelligent little insects because they know their weaknesses. They do not work in the daytime, not so often anyway, but at night when the little kids go to bed. They then attack very furiously only to give their victims a very rude shock the next day when they get up to find that their faces blemished with red spots. I hope, Sir, that this problem can also be eradicated as soon as possible.

Column: 1047



     The Chairman: Your 10 minutes are up, Mr Yap.

     Dr Ong Leong Boon (Kim Seng): Sir, I notice that the Hon. Minister for National Development is not only present alone in this Chamber but with him also is the very high-powered team from his Ministry. I am just wondering whether their presence here is to help him identify the problem constituencies or the problem Members of Parliament!

    Sir, we know that the answers given by the Hon. Minister yesterday had, in fact, mollified many of the Members in voicing their unhappiness, particularly MPs of old Housing and Development Board estates. My constituency is also a pretty old one with about 45% of the flats essentially of the one-room type. The schemes that were listed yesterday will in many ways affect me and my constituents, and I thought this would be an opportune occasion to raise this subject once again with the Minister.

    To me, the most important point when plans are afloat for constituency development or redevelopment is that the Ministry might wish to consider consultations with the local Member of Parliament or those who are holding responsible positions within the constituency. I appreciate that there could be certain matters in the development plans which could be sensitive and should not be made known other than Ministry officials. But where it affects the general redevelopment, like beautifying the constituency, uplifting facilities and so forth, perhaps those who work on the ground and who have full knowledge of the ground, the people and the problems and who know their aspirations, should be consulted. It is not necessary that all their views should be adopted. But I think it is a point worth considering.

    Very often we also notice that the plans which have come through and are filtered all the way down from the 25th floor of the National Development Building might carry flaws. I do not know if the paper exercise can also be improved upon with those who know the ground and who can offer suggestions.

Column: 1048



    The next problem, as I can see it, is the question of the survey conducted by the Housing and Development Board sometime towards the second half of last year when all one-room flat dwellers were sent survey forms informing them that their flats were due for demolition or conversion. In this circular, no time-table was laid out and, therefore, quite naturally, the constituents got pretty excited. I think it is important that when a survey like this is carried out, the residents should be informed as to when they will be affected. Some naturally will be very happy because it offers prospects of larger flats. Equally, there will be many who will not be too happy and very concerned because, to them their total family income can only give them that much money to live in one-room flats. That is why we have the rationale for preserving some of these flats. Whatever it is, whether they are happy or sad, they are all excited. So they all rush to their local Members of Parliament seeking reassurance and clarification. I think this is unfortunate because very often the local Member of Parliament is equally ignorant to advise the constituents as to what are the actual plans. In this particular matter, I think there should be more liaison or more knowledge should be provided to the local Member of Parliament or those in authority, like the Citizens' Consultative Committee or the Management Committee so that the information can be filtered down to the ground and where reassurance is required it could be given.

    This lack of communication was high-lighted in one classic example in my constituency. Following the survey, I was told that (for the sake of not exciting my constituents any further, I shall call the blocks of flats, Block A, B and C) Block A was the condemned block. Within a short period, I was again told that it would not be Block A but Block B. After I made further inquiries, I was told this time that Blocks A and B were spared, but Block C would be affected. This is the kind of situation which seems to be happening. I do not know whether it ties up with the change of guard within the Ministry.

    Another point which I would like to raise - it has been raised earlier - concerns the

Column: 1049

cleanliness of the estate. I had earlier on raised this matter with the Minister for the Environment and he had very conveniently passed it on to the Ministry of National Development, and I am therefore bringing this matter up. Of late we notice that the cleanliness of the estates in certain areas is lacking. There is a lot of littering. I have gone round and seen broken bottles, glass, empty cans dumped into drains, thereby clogging up certain areas of the constituency. I understand that this is due to the problem with sub-contract workers. I would like to know from the Hon. Minister whether he has any plans to ensure that workers who are supposed to clean the estates are really there to clean the estates. This is a perennial problem and I think with his new vigour and his ability to offer solutions on the spot, I am sure he can come up with the answer.

    The next problem is barbed wires which has been raised in the Chamber before. This is about the dangers of barbed wires surrounding saplings and shrubs within constituencies, and very often these are found near children's playgrounds. I think it is very unwise to have barbed wires around saplings and along footpaths as many children have been injured. I have raised this point before, and time and again I find that new barbed wires are placed because new trees are planted. Perhaps this is something which he would like to look into. I had a horrifying sight on television during the by-elections when the TV screen was taken with the barbed wires in front and showing the candidate at the back. At that moment I was very horrifyingly reminded of "barbed wire mentality", and I do hope the HDB has not been infected with this.

    A more mundane matter for me and my constituents is the development of my constituency, and this is a point which I have raised several times. This is with regard to development plans around Taman Ho Swee. At the moment, there are about 11 blocks of flats on top of this hill and access steps are too steep. Some terracing could be done. There are also two refuse bins there which could surely be reduced to one because they are both sandwiched between eight blocks of

Column: 1050

flats. I know it is nice to have the smell equally shared by all the constituents but I think it is better, all things considered, that this smell pollution be reduced to a minimum.

    The next matter is with regard to the road itself. It is a cul-de-sac and I wonder whether the road leading to Taman Ho Swee could be extended in some way down to Zion Road or Havelock Road. I notice that there are development plans for new multi-storey car parks and I wonder whether, in fact, this road could be extended to the top of the carpark, which is many floor levels below, and from there lead out to the lower ground level roads at Havelock Road or Zion Road.

     Mr P. Selvadurai (Kuo Chuan): Sir, I merely want to raise two concrete situations for which provision ought to be made either in the Housing Board's rules or in terms of Housing Board's policies. The first one, Sir, concerns an old lady of 62 years old who has been going in and out of Woodbridge Hospital a number of times simply because Woodbridge Hospital, the place where she ought to be for any length of time, was unable to keep her.
